### Conflicts
Reviewers, this pull request conflicts with the following ones:

* [#23352](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/23352) (test: Extend stale_tip_peer_management test by MarcoFalke)
* [#2
ACK faaba842d03762591f8612fd1fb16c93c881913f \nRan functional tests on Ubuntu 16 and glanced through the code.
Added a commit to remove a shared global in the test, which caused non-determinism.
Force pushed a `CConnmanTest::ReceiveMsgFrom` to separate the test logic from the net logic
Concept ACK to be notified on rebase.
@MarcoFalke could you rebase this (if there isn't any other PR that should be reviewed first), and comment in regards to: https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/18470#discussion_r431027856.
Concept ACK: more type safety is better :)

<!--cf906140f33d8803c4a75a2196329ecb-->
üêô This pull request conflicts with the target branch and [needs rebase](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#rebasing-changes).

<sub>Want to unsubscribe from rebase notifications on this pull request? Just convert this pull request to a "draft".</sub>
This seems unrelated to `std::chrono::` / time refactoring.
Can you clarify why you're using `count_seconds` here rather than `.load().count()`?

The type of `time - g_last_tip_update.load()` should be assumed to be `std::chrono::something`, but the exact type should be assumed to be unknown, since it can change in a future refactor. Therefore, we need to somehow specify what precision we want to log to the debug log.\n\nUsing the `count_*` helpers is one way and I bet there are also other ways to achieve the same.
I recommend reviewing #18638 , which adds documentation to `count_seconds`
